p: Rev-erb α/β also repress inflammatory response in macrophages [ 5], and this may be physiologically pertinent to alphaviruses, as macrophages are involved in joint damage induced by infection and host response [ 1, 2, 13]. In an in vitro co-culture system, we show that Rev-erb agonist can suppress macrophage transcript levels of select inflammatory genes (IL6, TNFα, CCL2, and MMP9) ( Figure 2B), which are involved in rheumatoid arthritis [ 14] and implicated in alphavirus-induced joint pathology [ 15]. Additional studies may be warranted to determine if Rev-erb agonists can suppress arthritogenesis after CHIKV infection in vivo. Plasma levels of SR9009 have been reported to reach up to 20 μM in murine studies [ 6], near the range we tested in our in vitro studies (10–20 μM).
